Award.AwardTitle: Biological links between rhythm and reading

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Learning to read is the cornerstone of education. Recently, it has been discovered that the better you are at keeping a beat (e.g., accurately tapping along to a metronome or tapping out a beat in music) the better you are at reading. This raises fundamental questions about the overlapping brain and behavioral bases of reading and rhythmic abilities. This project measures sound-induced brainwaves in the auditory neural system in a search for "neural signatures" that are shared between people who are good readers and those who are good at keeping a beat. Once these signatures are established, they can be used to hone programs such as school-based music instruction that emphasize rhythmic skills in order to best encourage the parts of the brain that support reading and literacy.

The investigators will examine the overlap in the neural resources drawn upon by reading and rhythm. By measuring neural responses they will test the hypothesis that two types of rhythmic skills, synchronizing to a metronomic beat and extracting a beat from a complex rhythm, involve different brain regions, subcortical and cortical, respectively. The hypothesis is that the two rhythmic skills relate to temporal precision in the brainstem and phase-locking of ongoing cortical oscillations and contribute independent sources of variance to reading ability. By comprehensively testing rhythmic and reading skills in secondary school students, an age group old enough to perform the required rhythmic tasks but in whom reading skills are continuing to emerge, the investigators hope to further our understanding of reading and rhythm in relation to the unique contributions of subcortical and cortical auditory areas. In so doing, this work might guide the development of teaching strategies to optimize language skills for all children and remediation programs for poor readers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For some time, there has been an established link between rhythm ability and reading ability. For example, the ability to tap to a beat is impaired in children with reading problems. It is thought that an integration of multisensory inputs--visual processing, auditory processing, and motor skills--is important for literacy. The fact that moving to a beat also relies on multisensory processing supports this relationship and motivates us to examine neural foundations that underlie this link between linguistic and musical processing.

In this study, we operationally define two aspects of rhythm: "synchronization" is the ability to keep time to a metronomic beat, and "sequencing" is the ability to detect stress patterns and recognize the beat of a complex rhythmic sequence. We hypothesized that that synchronization and sequencing are linked to distinct aspects of neural processing--slow/cortical and fast/subcortical neurophysiology, respectively--and therefore likely contribute to different aspects of language development.

We discovered that sequencing, which requires the integration of information across time, aligns with the consistency of low-frequency auditory cortical responses. The much faster synchronization aligns with the consistency of the frequency-following response, a largely subcortically generated response. Further, the cortical/sequencing and subcortical/synchronization pairs were linked to different abilities: verbal memory and reading, and nonverbal auditory temporal processing, respectively.

Additionally, we discovered that correcting synchronization performance via feedback plays a role in its relationship with both literacy and neural processing. Variability of synchronization while using visual feedback cues predicted phonological memory and other reading subskills. It also was consistent with more mature evoked cortical responses and resting-state cortical oscillatory activity.

Our research also has led to additional discoveries of relationships between rhythm ability and some non-linguistic skills such as attention and inhibitory control.

Together, these findings suggest that a rhythm-focused training regimen might be an efficient means of improving and supporting languages skills. As such, findings from this NSF-supported project have been equally well-received by translational scientists and clinicians interested in developing rhythm-based strategies for literacy and language interventions.
